thread.title: 18-Year-Old Woman Survived Oregon Mass Shooting by Playing Dead
thread.title_full: 18-Year-Old Woman Survived Oregon Mass Shooting by Playing Dead

author: Cosmopolitan.com
title: 18-Year-Old Woman Survived Oregon Mass Shooting by Playing Dead
text:
A gunman killed 10 people and wounded seven in a mass shooting at Oregon's Umpqua Community College on Thursday that's shocked the small, picturesque town of Roseburg, Oregon, and elicited a frustrated response from the president. Meanwhile, one of the wounded, 18-year-old Anastasia Boylan, shared her tale of survival in the moments before surgery.
According to CNN , which interviewed Boylan's parents, the 18-year-old was shot in the back by a bullet that traveled down her spine. She was lying on the floor bleeding, when the gunman said to her, "Hey you, blonde woman."
 Boyland played dead, her parents told CNN, and survived.
She told her parents about the horrifying deal before going into surgery to repair her spine.
Anastasia Boylan 18yo, shot in #OregonShooting . She says gunman reloaded, asking students to stand b4 shooting them. pic.twitter.com/QGOOgTzszm
— Kyung Lah (@KyungLahCNN) October 2, 2015
More From Cosmopolitan The shooting began shortly after 10:30 a.m. local time, when a 26-year-old man identified as Chris Harper Mercer — ​ the sheriff refused to name the shooter, claiming it would serve to glorify him — ​ entered a public speaking classroom and began his deadly assault.
According to Boylan, Mercer stopped to reload his gun after his first salvo of bullets, ordering the students to rise and asking if they were Christians.
"And they would stand up and he said, 'Good, because you're a Christian, you're going to see God in just about one second,'" Boylan's father told CNN .
He then shot them.
The incident at Umpqua Community College is only the latest in a string of mass shootings in public places, including schools, movie theaters, churches, and shopping malls. President Obama on Thursday delivered a 13-minute speech filled with emotion and frustration over the nation's collective responses to these tragedies, saying it's become routine and that the U.S. is now numb to these horrors.
"Our thoughts and prayers are not enough," he said. "It's not enough. It does not capture the heartache and grief and anger that we should feel. And it does nothing to prevent this carnage from being inflicted someplace else in America next week or a couple months from now."
In the hours after the tragedy in Oregon, hundreds of people in the small community of Roseburg held a candlelight vigil at a park on Thursday night.
"In our sorrow, we will remember and honor those lost here today," Oregon Gov. Kate Brown said at the vigil. "And in this way, they will live forever in our hearts."
Follow Michael on Twitter.
